PSA about windows update in Windows 10:

Windows Update now has a feature that shares updates you download through the internet, it's P2P file sharing which can use up your internet bandwidth by seeding update files to other windows 10 computers. I recommend you turning this off to avoid bandwidth issues. 

From the start menu:

>Click "Settings"

>Click "Update and security"> "Windows update"> "Advanced Options"> "Choose how updates are delivered" and set this slider to OFF:

![BixcZ7p.png](http://i.imgur.com/BixcZ7p.png)

> 
> PSA about windows update in Windows 10:
> Windows Update now has a feature that shares updates you download through the internet, it's P2P file sharing which can use up your internet bandwidth by seeding update files to other windows 10 computers. I recommend you turning this off to avoid bandwidth issues.

I would think that sharing between local machines would LESSEN your bandwidth, allowing all computers on your network to benefit from a single download.

I agree that turning off P2P over the internet is a good idea if you're bandwidth starved, though if you're feeling charitable (or don't otherwise care) it's neighborly.

> 
> I would think that sharing between local machines would LESSEN your bandwidth, allowing all computers on your network to benefit from a single download..

Yes, and if you are having trouble getting updates downloaded through MS' servers you could turn the feature back on 'till they finish. However i personally don't like applications using my internet without asking, it's bad enough you can't actually DELAY or STOP updates from downloading without win 10 pro. So this info may be useful for those who have very limited speeds and want to minimize how much bandwidth windows takes up. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-05T05:48:21Z" title="08/05/2015 05:48  AM" data-short="8 yr">August 5, 2015</time> by Camacha**

All true, but I'd still rather not willingly spill all my data to Google.

The likes of stagefright are *bugs*, Googles (and now MS too, it seems) constant datamining is an intentional *anti-feature* as far as I am concerned, and one I'd rather not have, even if it does make some things more convenient.

A kernel level firewall (e.g. iptables) also goes a fair way towards preventing apps (and potentially even the Android VM) from doing things they shouldn't.

I'd also consider "greener pastures", if I could see any hereabouts. I'm really not convinced MS or Apple are any better.

Of course, if you really want to go tinfoil hat, it's not the phone OS or apps you should be concerned about... It's the firmware on the radio chipset. ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)

The best defence, IMO, against both intentional and unintentional privacy leaks is information... knowing what (and whose) code is actually running and what security flaws it may have.

I see a couple of options. Dropping the smartphone and going back to a featurephone, or Blackberry. Yes, I know, but it actually has a lot going for it compared to the other three. The main concern would be whether it can survive and stay an independent phone maker, plus you would obviously give up some flexibility and bang for buck.

> 
> Regarding stagefright, it's already been patched by both Google and CyanogenMod (possibly other vendors also).
> Getting the update out might be more interesting though. In the mean time, stagefright (and HW media decoding ![:(](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_sad.gif)) can be disabled fairly easily.
> 
> If you're slightly less concerned, AFAIK MMS is the only vector currently in the wild... so turn off auto retrieval.

Thing is, a lot of perfectly fine and even quite new phones will never see the update. Waiting it out will not do in a lot of cases - only recent flagships will be sure to get updates and custom ROMs are also not available in all the appropriate versions. It really is a huge terrible mess.

By the way, MMS is not the only vector. Any website can load malicious videos too, as can Whatsapp probably (and other apps). Currently the only known browser to have plugged the leak is Firefox, so it is probably best to use that. It still leaves the bugs unharmed though, so things like social engineering and a worm sending videos through your friends, making you think it is safe are all still feasible.

Like I said, I am going to see how this plays out. If Google does not change the laissez faire attitude and actually do something (rather than just update their latest branch and call it done), I cannot image continuing using my current phone, and I can also not see myself getting another Android device knowing the same could happen at any time again.
